Course Section: AMNE_V 160-002 - Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Jewish, Christian, and Muslim Religious Traditions. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.

** This course has TWO required sections: a lecture and a discussion. This lecture section only meets MW. Please email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with your ranked preference for Friday’s discussion section. You will be assigned to a discussion section depending on your enrolment time and seat availability.**
The discussion sections are: 
AMNE 160 L2A: F 12-1 pm
AMNE 160 L2B:  F 1-2 pm
AMNE 160 L2C:  F2-3 pm

Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section. If the course is blocked by showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

Course Section: AMNE_V 160-L2D - Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Steps for registration:

** This course has TWO required sections: a lecture and a discussion. **

Please register for AMNE 160 L2D in order to complete your registration for AMNE 160 002 (lecture). WD will not allow you to register for the lecture section unless you also register for this DISC section (AMNE 160 L2D).
This lecture section only meets MW. Please email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with your ranked preference for Friday’s discussion sections. You will then be moved from L2D into your assigned discussion section (L2A, L2B, or L2C) depending on your enrolment time and seat availability.

The discussion sections options are:
AMNE 160 L2A: F 12-1 pm
AMNE 160 L2B:  F 1-2 pm
AMNE 160 L2C:  F2-3 pm

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section. If the course is blocked by showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

Temples, Tombs, and Tyrants: The Archaeology of the Middle East, Greece, and Rome. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions. 
If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section. If the course is blocked by showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

This course explores the diverse tapestry of human cultures through the lens of cultural anthropology. It examines fundamental concepts, methodologies, and thematic explorations shaping this field of study. From language to politics, from rituals to virtual spaces, cultural anthropologists analyze the intricacies of societies worldwide. Through lectures, discussions, and immersive activities, we will explore the notion of 'culture' and the method of participant-observation. Engaging with ethnographic accounts, we will investigate the familiar and the unfamiliar, learning to challenge perspectives, question norms, and cultivate critical thinking.

This course introduces students to the study of human society through centring culture, social systems, and institutions. Students will learn about the methods and concepts that cultural anthropologists use to analyse the relationship between social change, power, and human behaviour. Through topics like media, gender, migration, climate change, and colonialism (among others), the course explores how human beings shape and are shaped by the world around them. Students will learn how to think about their relations with others and their everyday lives through an anthropological perspective.
